div1.p: [Kean] gives a brief summary of conditions in Cuba before the arrival of the Yellow Fever Board. He provides an account of the activities of the Board, which ultimately shows the mosquito as the bearer of yellow fever. Included are notes by Truby.

places in pencil. “Lazear wrote”

Kean

Sanitary Work in Cuba.
First Introduction

Before the outbreak of the Spanish War the Army was as placid and pacific an
institution as the sun looked down upon in his diurnal journey. Lookping back from
the strenuousness of the succeeding decade we can truly say in the words of the
Psalmist that “its ways were ways of pleasantness and all its paths were peace”.
The Medical Department shared in the I nocuous desuetude of this idylic existence
and was a very subordinate factor of military life. I cannot recall in the 14 years
of my service previous to 1898 any mention of the Medical Department in the Reports
of the Secretary of War or the speeches or messages of the President or in any im-
portant publication. Since the beginning of the new era our Corps and its works are
much in the public eye and are frequently in evidence in the utterances and writings
of the President and the Secretary of War. Our status has greatly changed and grown
in importance. Without disparagement to the excellent work which has been done by
the Medical Corps in Porto Rico the Philippines the Isthmus of Panama and elsewhere
it is not too much to say that this change is due in great part to the sanitary re-
generation of Cuba and primarily to the extinction of yellow fever in the Island.

It seems not unreasonable therefore that the President of this School should
desire that this the largest class in its historythe medical officers just intering the service should have some familiarity with
the details of that glorious work, and should demand them of one who was on the
ground and in intimate association with the principal performers. My only regret
is that I have not the practice and facility in speaking to which you are accustomed
in the learned professors who usually occupy this platform which would enable me to
give to the story the interest which it deserves.

div1.p:
It is safe to assume that you all have a general familiarity with
the classical experiments of the Reed Commission, but I think for members
of the Medical Corps of the Army a somewhat more intimate and accurate
knowledge should be expected and I have arranged to have placed in your
hands for the future personal use of each a copy of the Compilation made by Capt Sen of the S.G.O. and print-
ed by Congress at the request of the S. G. which includes all of Reeds own reports of his work in
Cuba, together with articles throwing light upon other parts of this great
work by Carroll, Gorgas, Finlay and Havard. The memorandaums in the 3rd
and 4th chapters were prepared by me and include I believe the names of
all individuals who took part, either as conductors or as the subjects of
these experiments. As the story is told fully and in official form in
this valuable publication, I will not go into details which are told in itnarrated there
but, if you will pardon a rather personal and reminiscent narrative, I will
give you a brief account of conditions in Cuba before the arrival of the
Yellow Fever Board and some unpublished details with regard to their work.

When Santiago was captured by our troops it presented all the horrors
of a besieged city. Bodies of men and animals, dead of wounds or
disease were scattered through the streets and houses and as all sanitary services
had been abandoned during the siege the accumulation of filth made the
condition of affairs intolerable. General Leonard Wood was placed
in command of the city and the conquered territory and the energy and
thoroughness with which he brought the city into a good sanitary condition
and organized a government attracted wide-spread attention and laid the
foundation of his future career. Colonel Valery Havard was appointed
as chief surgeon on August 7, 1898 and continued as chief surgeon of the
department of Santiago until his transfer in 1900 to Havana where he
occupied a like position for the division of Cuba.

I accompanied the 7th Army Corps to Cuba, being Chief Surgeon, 1st Division
and landed in Havana Dec. 28, 1898, just in time to be with my Division Commander
Gen. Keifer (nowlately a representative in Congress from Ohio) at the imposing ceremonies
incident to the transfer of the Sovereignty over Cuba from Spain to the United States.
Sitting on our horses on the Prado we saw the red and yellow flag hauled down from
the flagstaff of the Morro where it has floated for nearly four centuries (with one
brief interruption,) and saw its place taken by the Stars and Stripes. Three years
and five months later I saw the American flag give place on the same staff to the
Cuban.

Cuba was for the purposes of government a military division divided in 1898
into seven military departments corresponding in limits to the six provinces and the
city of Havana. The number of departments was reduced after Gen. Leonard Wood was
transferred from Santiago to Havana as the successor to Gen. Brooke and after a couple
of years Cuba was made one single Department.

The whole country outside of the cities was laid waste and the latter were fillinged
with starving reconcentrados, who had to be furnished food and tools and work animals
in order to be established in their desolate homes in the country. The cities were
in a state of indiscribable filth and neglect and in every tained breeze we feared to
inhale the mysterious infection of the dreaded yellow fever. There was no central
sanitary organization but each of the even Chief Surgeons went bravely to work to
solve his own problems without other expert assistance than the occassional advice of
the Chief Surgeon of the Division whose supervision was however confined largely to
the military administration. This lack of bureaucratic organization lasted through-
out the period of the first intervention, and it is highly creditable to the medical
officers and others concerned in the sanitary work of the military government that
such good results were attained under so loose a system.

In Havana where were the greatest problems, Major Gorgas was Chief Surgeon, but
3

Within a few months after the establishment of American control
Havana and the other principal cities of Cuba were clean, the streets
were being repaired, and garbage regularly removed. This service was in
Havana under an officer of the Engineer Department, Col. Wm. M. Black, and
was admirably organized, the relation of the Sanitary Department to it being
inspectorial only. The placing of houses and private premises in a
sanitary condition was in charge of the Sanitary Department and was like-
wise carried on with great energy. The first cleaning up was done by
the sanitary gangs and householders were thereafter required to maintain
a proper state of cleanliness. The organization of the other and more
technical functions of a Sanitary Department such as the collection of
vital statistics, the reporting and investigation of contagious diseases,
the establishment of laboratories, the enforcement of vaccination, etc.,
took a longer time.

during the first year, he was not permitted to have any thing to do with the sanitary
administration of the City which was under a volunteer surgeon better known for per-
sonal energy than for scientific attainment. When some comment was made to the
General who was Governor of the city, a distinguished officer of Engineers, as to the
peculiarity of this arrangement he was said to have replied “Oh in that matter I pre-
fer to furnish my own brains” When in Dec. 1899 he offered me the position of Chief
Sanitary Officer of Havana I was compelled to think the compliment a somewhat dubious
one. Early in 1900 however both this General and his energetic sanitary officer de-
parted for the Philippines. The city of Havana was added to the Department of Gen.
Fitzhugh Lee on whose staff I was serving as Chief Surgeon and Major Gorgas became
Chief Sanitary Officer of the city reporting directly to Gen. Wood who had came into su-
preme command of the Island.

The work of the Sanitary Department in Havana consisted in house-to-house inspections of
dwelling houses, shops, factories, stables, &c., with the enforcement of sanitary con-
ditions - the disinfections of cases of infectious disease including very extensive
disinfections of houses, clothing, &c., for yellow fever, the regulation of the markets
and the collection of vital statistics. Within a few months after the establishment
American control the city was clean and garbage regularly removed. The organi-
tion of the other function of a sanitary department took longer.

I was doing work of the same sort in the garrisoned towns of the Province of
Havana and Pinar del Rio and had in addition the care of the orphan asylums which had
been established by Miss Clara Barton, President at that time of the American Red
Cross Society. This benevolent lady after renting the houses, employing teachers
and servants and collecting all that she could of the abundant crop of orphans left
by the victims of the reconcentration calmly sailed away to the United States without
provision for house-rents, services, or food, leaving the military Governor to hold
the bag. This Gen. Brooke promptly passed on to Gen. Lee and he in turn to his chief
surgeon. Thus I acquired 16 orphan asylums in one day. There were moreover public
hospitals in all the larger towns crowded with unhappy creatures perishing in filth
and neglect from every variety of disease. These had all been brought into order
4
4
and fairly good administration by April 1900. Col. E. St. John Guble F. A is entitle
to the credit of first bringing order & good administration into the institutions
under the Dept. of Charities. I succeeded him as Supt. of beneficincia in Gen. Woods Staff in April 1901.

Early in May of1900 Gen. Wood came out on a visit to Gen. Fitz Lee at Marianao
the town which was the Headquarters of the latter and near the post of Columbia Bar-
racks where were 1200 American Soldiers, and he remarked that it was cleaner than any New
England Village. The inhabitants endured our scrubbings and sweepings and disinfec-
tions with patient good humor accompanied by many shrugs, and the only Kick which I
recall was against the use of carbolic acid to disinfect cesspools because they said
it gave a bad taste to the water in the wells! We had all accepted the doctrine
that yellow fever was a filth disease and great was our consternation to find that
summer that cleanliness was no protection, and the disease which we all so frankly
dreaded went through Havana and Marianao, like a fire. In Marianao we finally only
checked it by forceably expelling from town all non-immunes and putting them in Camp.

It was in the midst of this epidemic on June 25th that Major Reed and Dr. Carroll
came to Cuba and organized the Yellow Fever Board, Drs. Lazear and Agramonte being
already there. I was at the time sick with the disease and Reed came the day he
landed out to the hospital at Columbia Barracks to see me. I believe that I was the
first yellow fever patient which he had ever seen for tho he had been in Havana for
three weeks in March. to investigate the use of electrozine as a disinfectant there was then very little fever in the city. The Board spent
the month of July in searching for the bacillus icteroides of Sanarelli both in the
blood and excretions of the sick and in the organs of the dead and was able to show
in 18 cases that it was not present, thus giving a final quietus to Sanarelli's
claims.

Reed and Agramonte had however in July investigated a sharp epidemic among the
American troops at Pinar del Rio and were particularly struck with the fact that a
prisoner in the guard house had been attacked altho he could not have been in any
infected locality and Dr. Agramonte says that the possibility of mosquito infection
was discussed with reference to this case and it was determined to try it. Carter's -
observation.

Dr. Carroll has stated that the final decision to make experiments on human
5
5
beings was made the night before Reed returned on August 1st to Washington to com-
plete the publication of the great Report on Typhoid Fever in the Volunteer Camps by
Reed. Vaughan and Shakespeare. (work on)The Board had before this talked on the subject with
Dr. Carlos J. Finlay. of Havana, who had maintained in numerous publications since
1881 the mosquito transmission of yellow fever and had made between that date and
Reed's first report no less than 103 experiments on human beings to demonstrate his
theory.-yet latho he had selected the right species of mosquito as the carrier he
did not succeed in producing the disease in a single case. The shortest interval.

It is very interesting to study these cases which were recorded in a careful
and scientific manner, for they show the extraordinary difficulties which the be-
ginners in this field had to encounter, and illustrate the admirable acumen with
which Reed drew his conclusions. Dr. Finlay reports 16 cases out of 103 as success-
ful but in order to do so he had to extend the incubation period to 25 days, altho.
In none of Reed's or Guiteras cases was the incubation period longer than 6 days.
Also it is my understanding that many of these cases were exposed to other sources
of infection. Rejecting the cases in which the incubation period was more than 6
days we have left four in none of which was there albuminuria and only one of which
presented the clinical symptoms of yellow fever. In none of these cases was the
mosquito infected by a case in the first three days of the disease and in none of
them had a longer period than 6 days elapsed since the mosquito had bitten the
infecting case and so was not ripe.

Applying our present knowledge that cases of yellow fever can only infect mos-
quitos in the first three days of the disease and secondly that a period of twelve
days must then pass before the mosquito becomes ripe and able to convey the infection.
we find that none of Dr. Finlay's cases fulfilled both of these conditions, and so
in 20 years of work we can safely say that he did not produce a single case of experi-
mental yellow fever. And yet with what Gorgas called “splendid scientific clairvoy-
ance” he held to his theory with unshaken tenacity.

It was between these two stools of the short infecting stage in the human patient
and the long incubation stage in the mosquito that Lazear fell in his first 9 experi-
ments all of which were failures, much to the discouragement of the Board. In the
two other cases of this series those of Carroll and X.Y. the mosquito had become ripe
and he promptly got results. The case X. XY. was bitten on August 31st the day that Dr.
Carroll was taken sick but before his sickness was recognized, and I think that it
deserves some mention on account of the immense importance of it.

Dr. Carroll who was at that time somewhat skeptical in the matter of mosquito
transmission had vitiated the value of his attack as a scientific experiment by going
into the infected zone and even to the yellow fever hospital after he was bitten and
during the period of incubation, and so it was on this case X.Y. that Reed rested the
burden of his proof in his Preliminary Note. It was the X.Y. case which convinced him.
AEJ

Reed was you remember in Washington in August and September and Lazear wrote to
him the account of these two cases. I happened to be in the city of Matanzas on Oct.
3rd when the transport came into that port with Reed on board and I went out to see him.
It was there that I heard for the first time the true story of X.Y. which had been kept
by Lazear a close secret. He wrote it to Reed but it is my impression that he told no
one at Camp. Columbia and J. altho. Ch. Surgeon of the Dept. and living only half an
mile from the hospital knew nothing of the facts in the case.

The story is this:- On the morning of Aug. 31st Lazear took seven mosquitos in-
cluding four that had bitten yellow fever patients, one of them being the insect which
had bitten Carroll 4 days before, into a ward of the hospital at Columbia Barracks and
said “Who will feed my mosquitos”. A good natured cavalryman, suffering or offered to do so.
AET

Whether he was told that the mosquitos had bitten yellow fever patients I do not know ?
but as these mosquitos had uniformly failed so far to cause infection the matter was
probably not regarded as very risky by Lazear and it is my impression that he did not
mention it. Next day the soldier was returned to duty and on Sept. 5th came back to
Hospital with yellow fever. Columbia barracks was at that time under strict quarrantine
which it was proved the soldier had observed so he had not been otherwise exposed and
7
7
the case was clear.

But the dread of yellow fever was so great and the orders of the military author-
ities so strict on the subject of exposure that it is probable that if the commanding
officer had found out that a purposely infected soldier had been let loose in the
midst of his 1200 non-immune men there would have been a great row and probably some
court-martials. So the man's name was concealed and Reed in writing his preliminary
note did not admit that he was a soldier. I laughed much at his efforts to conceal
this fact and told him that if he suppressed too many details the scientists would not
believe him while if he told them the military authorities would get him.

A year later when Carroll infected two soldiers Privates Hamann and Covington of
the Coast Artillery with filtered blood their commanding officer started out to make
trouble about it. But the victory had been won. Havana was free from yellow fever
and every one was happy and proud of this great triumph of our Corps. Besides it was
well known that the great authority of General Wood was behind these experiments. So
the communications of this officer were quietly pigeon-holed. But it would have
probably been far different in 1900.

It is however desirable now that this probably unconscious volunteer should have
his name added to the roll of honor and so a few days sincein 1910 I collected all the data
concerning him and had no difficulty in identifying his name on the Report of Sick and
Wounded of Columbia Barracks for Sept. 1900, as that of Pvt. William H. Dean, Troop B.
7th Cavalry, born in Ohio, aged 27 years.

I hope that the day is not far off when Congress will erect a statute to Walter
Reed in this city and that its pedestal will bear on three sides the portraits in
base-relief of Carroll, Lazear and Agremonte, while the fourth should contain the names
of those who submitted to these famous experiments. In this list the name of William
H. Dean should come next below that of Carroll.

To return to Dr. Finlay: He was able to indicate to Reed the actual variety of
mosquito which was the transmitter of the disease and to present him with its eggs
for breeding purposes. This suggestion must have been of much assistance to Reed's
Board for if they had begun with any other variety the technical difficulties of
breeding and handling the insects would have been far greater and the patience of the
Board might not have like that of Dr. Finlay stood the test of a long series of
failures. The stegomyia is a domesticated and tractible insect which breeds well
in captivity and is perfectly willing to bite any fist which is thrust into its jar.
In fact it can be carried in the pocket in a test tube plugged with cotton, and if
the plug is withdrawn and the mouth of the tube placed upon the patient's skin it
will promptly descend and bite. The common brown culex pungens cannot be got to
bite in this way, and in an experiment of Reed's with pungens he could only get them
to bite by placing them inside the mosquito bar of the patient. When he went to
collect them in the morning he found that the Spanish patient had taken his revenge
on them by killing them all. I think this ended the experiments with pungens

A couple of yeras ago I had occasion to ask Dr. Guiteras to make some experiments
to determine if mosquitos could get through wire gauze 16 meshes to the inch. He re-
ported that stegomyia could not, and I then suggested that he repeat the experiment
with pungens and anopheles when he protested humorously against having to work with
such wild creatures which insisted on dying and did not have the charming docility
of stegomyia.

But the preservation of even this gentle insect had its difficulties, one of
which was their liability to be devoured by a tiny red ant which was omnipresent
in Cuba. I remember one big jar of infected mosquitos nearly ripe at Camp Lazear
which were all devoured in one night in spite of jars of water under the legs of the
table on which it sat. It was found that the cord of the window shade had been
allowed to touch the table and had thus made a suspension bridge over which the ants
had made their foray.

To Reed's mind the case of Dean reenforced by that of Carroll established the
theory and his quick mind saw in a flash the vast importance of it. After the fate
of Lazear and the experience of Carroll he hardly expected that new volunteers would
be forthcoming. So in a visit to me at Gen. Lee's headquarters on Oct. 12th he told
me that he was going to Havana next morning to ask General Wood's permission to go
back to the United States, announce the discovery at the approaching meeting of the
American Public Health Association and consult Gen. Sternberg on what should be the
next step.

I told him I would drive him down in the General' aLee's carriage, and after we started
unfolded to him a scheme which had occurred to me. This was that as all Spaniards
when they came to Cuba landed with the expectation of getting yellow fever, it would
not be difficult with the help of money to persuade them to have their attack by
experimental inoculation. So Reed was to ask Gen. Wood for the money, and the quar-
antine camps at Triscornia where Spanish immigrants were at that time detained for
their own protection until they should get employment, was to furnish the Spaniards.
AEJ

I shall never forget the faces of the two men as we stood in a window of the Palace
at Havana looking out on the Plaza de Armas, and Reed with that lucidity and force of
speech which was characteristic of him told his story while Gen. Wood listened grave
impassive but alert. The two men knew each other well for Wood had taken a special
course at this school under Reed only three years before when a Captain in the Medical
Corps and assistant to the attending surgeon in this city. When Reed finished he
looked at Gen. Wood a moment and then asked if the General would give him the money#10000 to
employ Spaniards and continue the experiments. Instantly came the reply “I will give you
[unclear] thousand dollarsthe money and if that is not enough I will give you $100,000 more. I have
today given a large sum for the secret service and this is certainly vastly of greater
importance to Cuba than the catching of a few rogues”. Take no men who are not
sound in mind & body and of legal age by the Spanish law

We then went to lunch and I drank to a good voyage and to the great fame which
would surely come to him. In less than three weeks he was back again and the money
was placed by Gen. Wood's order to my credit for disbursement and we began to build the experimental
2 But at first he did not expect much of it & confesses in an report;

“I had very little hope of accomplishing much; it seemed to me that even
if the mosquito did convey yellow fever, he could not be gotten rid of, and,
apparently, from all past experience, the mosquito was not the only way, or
even the principal way, of conveying the disease. But as he evidently could
convey the disease, it was our duty to take precautions in this direction. . . .
10
station at Camp Lazear. From this point on I imagine the story is familiar to you all.

The conversion of Gorgas to the new theory was complete by the first of February
1901, and during that month he began to make practical application of it. In his ✗
sanitary report for the month of February which is dated March 6th he says:
“During February 1900 we had 17 cases of yellow fever, in Feb. of 1901 we had 8
new cases. As the number of non-immunes was very much larger in Feb. of this
than in that of last year I think the showing is encouraging. Besides disinfecting the
houses with formaline and other disinfectants we could screen the rooms occupied by
a yellow fever patient as soon as his case is reported and kill all the mosquitos in
the building with fumes of pyrethrum powder, at the same time covering with kerosene
oil all places where mosquitos can breed about the building. We also kill the mosquitos
in all the adjoining buildings in the same way. With these measures and the steps we
are taking to kill the mosquitos in the suburbs I hope to markedly decrease the yellow
fever in the coming summer.

The history of yellow fever in Havana shows that in Jan. Feb. and March there is
a gradual decrease, these cases being the alftermath of the preceding year, and after the
first of April it begins to slowly increase again and so it was the custom of sanitarian
to count the epidemic year for yellow fever to begin April 1st. It was then a very
favorable time for Gorgas to begin his campaign when the number of mosquitos was at
the minimum - and also the number of cases.

The method of work and the difficulties encountered are very well told in a report
dated Dec. 29, 1901, of the work done by the Stegomyia Brigade during the 8 months
since its organization - for very soon it was found necessary to divide the mosquito
work into that of the Anopheles Brigade which operated in the suburbs and the Stegomyia
Brigade which made house and back yard inspections. These separate organizations still
operate in Havana. It may be of interest to know that Mr. Joseph A. Le Prince who
wrote this report whenis with Col. Gorgas in Panama and is in charge of the mosquito
work there today. (See Rep. p. 101, Vol. IV, 1901).
La Prince said

I have the honor to present herewith a brief report on the difficul-
ties encountered, results obtained, and methods followed in reducing the
number of mosquitoes in the City of Havana and its suburbs during the past
eight months.

Previous to April, 1901, our Sanitary Inspectors made reports of those
houses where larvae were found and such houses were subsequently visited
and the deposits of water containing larvae were treated with petroleum.
It soon became evident, however, that so many breeding places existed in
the vicinity of the houses that it was found necessary to establish a spe-
cial brigade to go over the City from house to house. The stegomyia bri-
gade was started in April and was gradually enlarged to forty men.

As many parts of this city are without water supply the people store
water in barrels, “tinajones”, cans, etc., etc., and it is in deposits of
this character that the greater number of Stegomyia larvae are found. It
might be mentioned also that even in the houses where city water is obtain-
able water was kept stored in deposits.

Rain water being soft is kept in large quantities for washing pur-
poses. Considering all these matters, it is not surprising to find that
when we began our mosquito destruction work there was an average of one
deposit of water containing larvae for every house in the City.

Mosquitoes were also breeding in many ditches and puddles and also
in many wells, cisterns, tanks, “Fosas Mouras” and cess-pools, so it was
quite natural that the number of mosquitoes in Havana should have been
very large during past years.

Soon after the Stegomyia Brigade started we oiled all deposits of
water which were being used and requested the people to keep petroleum
on the surface of the water and draw water from the base of each vessel
by means of a tap. This method, although it killed the larvae, was found
to be impractical because a large number of people seemed afraid that the
12
12.
oil was poisonous and in many cases people skimmed the oil off and each
heavy rain removed all the petroleum and spoiled our work.

Another plan had to be adopted. It was decided that two boards a
foot wide and two feet long could be put together rapidly and nailed
over each barrel, etc. In the center of the lid so made, a square hole
8″ × 8″ was cut and over it was nailed a piece of wire gauze; such a lid
was then ready to nail on the deposit and in a moment a hole could be
made below to draw water from. Lids of this form were made in large num-
bers and were nailed over the Darrels belonging to the people in desti-
tute circumstances. Also on May 25th the following order was issued and
delivered at 26,000 houses:

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA.
Office of Chief Sanitary Officer of Havana,
Notice to Tenants and Property Owners.

It is known that the yellow fever mosquito (Stegomyia) prefers to lay
its eggs in clear and quiet waters, and in order to destroy this mosquito,
the Sanitary Department has issued the following order:

The covers of all wells, cisterns, tanks or any other vessel that may
at any time contain water shall be tightly covered in such a manner that
they shall be mosquito proof. All small entrance or cracks shall be prop-
erly covered or have wire gauze nailed over them. All cisterns and wells
shall be supplied with pumps. All wells and cisterns not in use shall
have their covers nailed down or shall be sealed.

Wherever barrels are used to contain water, they shall be supplied
with a clost fitting cover and in the center of each such cover shall be
left an opening about 6 inches square. This opening shall be covered with
a piece of fine mosquito proof wire netting and will serve as entrance for
water to be kept in the barrel. At the bottom of the barrel a tap shall
be placed.

Hereafter no person shall be allowed to have barrels or other vessels
containing water which are not mosquito proof.

The above order having been made a law, must be obeyed and any person
violating the same will be held responsible.

Respectfully,
(Signed) W. C. Gorgas,
Major and Surgeon, U.S. Army,
Chief Sanitary Officer.

Immediately following the distribution of this law the Brigadee were
ordered to break all non-mosquito-proof barrels containing water. Our
13
13.
Stegomyia Brigade is composed of several divisions and each such divisions
contains one foreman and two laborers who carry petroleum. The foreman en-
ters a house, examines all parts of the yard, sees that the laborer who is
with him puts the correct quantity of oil in each drain, fosa moura, sewer
basin, pozo negro, etc., etc. He next goes up onto the balconies and roofs
of the houses to see if any deposits of water exist there. This work is
all absolutely necessary for there are many ignorant persons who persist in
breeding mosquitoes. In fact, as a rule little sympathy and still less
assistance is given to the mosquito work by the public in general. In
some sections of the City until lately, as soon as one of our divisions
appeared the tenants would lock up their deposits of water containing lar-
vae in the rooms until the Brigades had passed. In order to remove such
difficulties a list of names of all people who have deposits of water at
present has been made, and inspections of these are being made at irregu-
lar intervals and the owners are being fined when larvae are found on their
premises. This method of procedure is producing excellent results. In the
daily routine each foreman enters in his books a report of each deposit of
water in non-mosquito-proof condition with the name of the owner thereof.
By this means we obtain each week lists of all wells, cisterns, tanks, etc.,
and orders are sent at once notifying owners to make same mosquito-proof.
It has been found practical by this means and by the enforcement of the
order previously mentioned to have all deposits of water made and kept
mosquito proof, and a glance at the summary attached to this report will
show what has been done. It has not been found practical to get assist-
ance from house tenants and so they have been forced rather than persuaded
to obey the orders of this Department. Eternal vigilance is necessary, for
at one time we left one section of the city without inspection for a period

to state that many new deposits of water with larvae were found and also that

In November a notice was published in the papers that thereafter all
persons having receptacles with water which is found to contain larvae, will
be fined $10.00 U.S. currency for every violation of said law.

From the difficulties we have encountered it might be supposed that
there has not been a large decrease in the number of mosquitoes in this
City. This is not the case. In fact, we have been exceptionally success-
ful in our work and we hear good reports from all parts. Today, there are
many parts of this city where a hundred houses may be inspected one after
another without encountering any mosquito larvae. When you consider that
the average used to be one deposit per house exclusive of wells, cisterns,
tanks, etc., and also the fact that there are very few people who try to
assist us, then it is certainly gratifying to know that so much good work
has been accomplished. Mosquitoes were very numerous in Havana last sum-
mer and it was necessary to sleep under a mosquito bar every night. Our
soldiers at the Punta used to burn smudge every night to drive the mosqui-
toes out. This year these same men do not even use mosquito bars. We are
receiving similar reports from different parts of the city. When a suspect
case of yellow fever has occurred in this city the house of the patient and
the adjacent houses are fumigated to kill any infected Stegomyia present,
and all dead mosquitoes found are burned. It has been noticed that the num-
ber of dead mosquitoes found after fumigating is decreasing and also that
of those found the percentage of Stegomyia mosquitoes has decreased largely.

This will have an effect in reducing the possibility of yellow fever
patients being bitten. In our inspections I have found that the largest
quantity of Stegomyia larvae are found in house yards in vessels contain-
ing clear and still water. Even though water in pools contaminated with
sewage were close at hand containing (culex pungens) larvae the Stegomyia
seems to prefer the clearer water. There seems to be a popular impres-
sion that mosquitoes will not breed in moving water, but in Havana we
find them breeding in ditches and creeks which have considerable current
and also in the troughs where animals drink. In several cases tanks have
been found where water was running in at one end and out at the other and
many larvae were found to be present. Such tanks have been ordered to be
completely emptied twice a week or owner to be fined when larvae were found.
Even the tubs into which blacksmiths put red hot irons daily were found
to contain many larvae.
